title: Attorneys’ Fees Not Recoverable. Does CA law force the losing side in a junk-debt-buyer limited civil case to pay atty/court $
question: Category: Collections - Limited civil. I’m being sued by a junk debt buyer. Causes of action: 1st: Breach of contract; 2nd: Common Counts, including, among others, account stated. I used the affirmative defense in my Answer.
answers: prevailing party is entitled to recovery of court costs set forth in CCP 1032 and 1033 and attorney fees if based on statute or a contract. The cardmember agreement usually has an attorney fees clause in it. These amounts are asked for post trial.

Ordinarily, the issue of adding attorney fees to the judgment comes up after trial is over and the judgment has been rendered. Then the prevailing party submits a cost bill and may file a motion for attorney fees if there is a proper ground--either a contract providing for attorney fees to the prevailing party or a statute to that effect. This is because the "American rule" is that unless there is an agreement between the parties or a specific statute, all parties bear their own attorney fees in litigation. (Some costs are recoverable anyway, such as filing fees and service of process fees.)

Since your agreement specifies that the prevailing party is not to recover attorney fees, that could be used to oppose a motion for attorney fees.

You might want to consult with a local attorney about what to do at trial if you are determined to try the case yourself. The debt collector will be represented by counsel, and it would help if you were, too.

Plaintiff may recover attorney fees if judgment is entered based on an "open book account" claim (a type of common count). "Open book account" is defined by CCP Section 337a. California Civil Code Section 1717.5 explains the attorney fees: http://law.onecle.com/california/civil/1717.5.html.

Plaintiff may also recover certain costs, such as the court's fee to file the complaint and the process server's fee to serve the summons and complaint. These costs will be added to the judgment along with attorney fees.

Once the judgment has been entered, the unpaid balance will accrue 10% interest per year. Most judgment enforcement costs may be added, as well.

If you've been used, I suggest you consult with a debt collections defense attorney regarding your options.
